You have not visited all chapters of the training course. Therefore the test cannot be started. Please click on "Menu" to check the missing pages.

Sie haben noch nicht alle Seiten des WBTs bearbeitet, daher kann der Abschlusstest noch nicht gestartet werden. Klicken Sie auf den Button „Seitenmenü“, um zu kontrollieren, welche Seiten noch fehlen.
Fehler beim Lesen des XML-Manifests. Die Anwendung wird geschlossen.
Erreur lors de la lecture de XML-Manifest. L'application est fermée.
Errore nella lettura del manifesto XML. L´applicazione viene chiusa.
读取 XML-Manifest 时出错。 正在关闭应用程序。
Error al leer el XML-Manifest. Se cerrará la aplicación.
Fehler beim Lesen des Content-XML. Die Anwendung wird geschlossen.
Erreur lors de la lecture de XML-Content. L'application est fermée.
Errore nella lettura del contenuto XML. L´applicazione viene chiusa.
读取 Content-XML 时出错。 正在关闭应用程序。
Error al leer el Content-XML. Se cerrará la aplicación.
Fehler beim Lesen des QTI-XML. Die Anwendung wird geschlossen.
Erreur lors de la lecture de QTI-XML. L'application est fermée.
Errore nella lettura del QTI XML. L´applicazione viene chiusa.
读取 QTI-XML 时出错。 正在关闭应用程序。
Error al leer el QTI-XML. Se cerrará la aplicación.
Neither the LMS nor the accessing HTML page has provided a learning object number. Closing application.
Weder vom LMS noch von der aufrufenden HTML-Seite wurde eine Lernobjektnummer übergeben. Die Anwendung wird daher geschlossen.
Pas de numéro d´objet didactique transmis par LMS, ni par la page HTML consultée. L´application est donc fermée.
Sia LMS sia la pagina HTML di partenza non hanno comunicato un numero di oggetto di apprendimento. L´applicazione viene pertanto chiusa.
LMS 和访问的 HTML 页面都未提供学习对象编号。 正在关闭应用程序。
El LMS y la página HTML invocante no han asignado ningún número de objeto de aprendizaje. Por lo tanto, se cerrará la aplicación.
You require the Flash 6 plug-in or higher for this application. Closing application.
Für diese Anwendung benötigen Sie das Flash 6 Plugin oder höher. Die Anwendung wird nun geschlossen.
Pour cette application, le plugin Flash 6 ou + est nécessaire. L´application est maintenant fermée.
Per questa applicazione necessitate di Flash 6 Plugin o di una versione più recente. L´applicazione viene pertanto chiusa.
该应用程序需要 Flash 6 插件或更高版本。 正在关闭应用程序。
Esta aplicación requiere el complemento Flash 6 o superior. Se cerrará la aplicación.
Unfortunately you only have Flash version ' + flashVersion + '. You require Flash 6 or higher for this application. Closing application.
Sie haben leider nur die Flash-Version ' + flashVersion + '. Für diese Anwendung benötigen Sie Flash 6 oder höher. Die Anwendung wird nun geschlossen.
Vous n´avez malheureusement que la version Flash «+ flashVersion +». Pour cette application, le plugin Flash 6 ou + est nécessaire. L´application est maintenant fermée.
Purtroppo disponete soltanto della versione Flash ' + flashVersion + '. Per questa applicazione necessitate di Flash 6 o di una versione più recente. L´applicazione viene pertanto chiusa.
很遗憾，您的 Flash 版本仅是“+ flashVersion +”。 该应用程序需要 Flash 6 或更高版本。 正在关闭应用程序。
Tiene instalada únicamente la versión de Flash ' + flashVersion + '. Sin embargo, esta aplicación requiere Flash 6 o superior. Se cerrará la aplicación.
This browser does not support Javascript-based flash recognition. If the application does not start, please contact your system administrator.
Dieser Browser unterstützt die Javascript-basierte Flash-Erkennung nicht. Wenn die Anwendung nicht startet, wenden Sie sich bitte an Ihren System-Administrator.
Ce navigateur ne reconnaît pas Flash sur Javascript. Si l´application ne démarre pas, adressez-vous à votre administrateur système.
Il vostro browser non è in grado di riconoscere Flash basato su Javascript. Se l´applicazione non viene avviata, rivolgetevi all´amministratore del vostro sistema.
该浏览器不支持基于 Javascript 的 Flash 识别。 如果应用程序不启动，请与系统管理员联系。
Este navegador no admite la detección de Flash basada en Javascript. Si no se inicia la aplicación, diríjase a su administrador del sistema.
Do you really want to exit the lesson? Your learning status will be saved.
Wollen Sie wirklich das Programm beenden? Ihr Lernstand wird dann gespeichert.
Siete sicuri di voler terminare la lezione?
是否真的要退出本课程？ 将保存您的学习状态。
¿Desea realmente cerrar el programa? Se guardará su progresión de aprendizaje.
Do you want to pick up the lesson from where you left off, or do you want to start it again from scratch?
Wollen Sie die Lektion dort weiterbearbeiten, wo Sie sie zuletzt beendet haben oder wollen Sie die Lektion neu bearbeiten?
Souhaitez-vous poursuivre la leçon là où vous vous êtes arrêté la dernière fois, ou voulez-vous reprendre la leçon depuis le début?
Desiderate continuare la lezione, dove l´avete terminata durante l´ultima seduta oppure preferite ricominciare la lezione da capo?
是否接着上次的内容继续学习本课程，还是从头开始学习？
¿Desea continuar la lección en el punto donde la dejó por última vez o volver a verla entera?
Now we would like to know what you think about the behavior of the ${role} in the project.
Now we would like to know what you think about the behavior of the ${role} in the project.
…does not meet the requirements of this position

…did the best job they could do
…did the best job they could do

Architecture as well as continuous architectural governance
are key throughout the whole lifecycle and across releases.

Architecture as well as continuous architectural governance
are key throughout the whole lifecycle and across releases.
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles. What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles. What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
Build a pool of educated, i.e. certified architects and developers.
Build a pool of educated, i.e. certified architects and developers.
Consider architecture to be important throughout the entire lifecycle.
Consider architecture to be important throughout the entire lifecycle.
Empower architects to fulfill their roles and responsibilities successfully.
Empower architects to fulfill their roles and responsibilities successfully.
Enforce effective and efficient communication between architects and other stakeholders.
Enforce effective and efficient communication between architects and other stakeholders.
Focus on strategic design before turning to tactical design.
Focus on strategic design before turning to tactical design.
Use product-line engineering and platform approaches whenever appropriate.
Use product-line engineering and platform approaches whenever appropriate.

Foster review & refactoring activities.
…also as a way of communicating the architecture decisions and for early feedback

Foster review & refactoring activities.
…also as a way of communicating the architecture decisions and for early feedback

Emphasize on technologies instead of architecture.
Using of the shelf technologies saves time for architecture decisions

Emphasize on technologies instead of architecture.
Using of the shelf technologies saves time for architecture decisions
Leave out reviews during time-sensitive situations.
Leave out reviews during time-sensitive situations.
Save time by avoiding quality driven activities like refactoring
Save time by avoiding quality driven activities like refactoring
Written documents are contract proof. So avoid discussions. Use a Requirements Tool instead
Written documents are contract proof. So avoid discussions. Use a Requirements Tool instead
In an agile environment we don’t need strategic design or architecture decisions
In an agile environment we don’t need strategic design or architecture decisions

Always use a platform approach to save money.
Put as much functionality in the platform as possible to save cost.

Always use a platform approach to save money.
Put as much functionality in the platform as possible to save cost.
Refactoring can be avoided by good planning
Refactoring can be avoided by good planning

Pay particular attention to specifying, testing, and realizing non-functional requirements (NFRs),
often overlooked but extremely important.

Pay particular attention to specifying, testing, and realizing non-functional requirements (NFRs),
often overlooked but extremely important.
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles. What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles. What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, allocate, and verify NFRs. Test feasibility of riskful NFRs
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, allocate, and verify NFRs. Test feasibility of riskful NFRs
Identify conflicts in NFRs and identify overly ambitious NFRs.
Identify conflicts in NFRs and identify overly ambitious NFRs.
Convey the implementation difficulty(including time and budget) to the stakeholders instead of just enjoying the technical challenges.
Convey the implementation difficulty(including time and budget) to the stakeholders instead of just enjoying the technical challenges.
Insist on perfecting NFRs before starting the architectural design or measuring the NFRs of the platform.
Insist on perfecting NFRs before starting the architectural design or measuring the NFRs of the platform.
Attempt to build a system to address all stakeholders' inputs (only).
Attempt to build a system to address all stakeholders' inputs (only).
Decide on an NFR’s value without checking the prototype measurements.
Decide on an NFR’s value without checking the prototype measurements.
Think and design for the most important NFR without considering others.
Think and design for the most important NFR without considering others.
Strive for transparency and base decisions on clear business / technical (not political) reasons.
Strive for transparency and base decisions on clear business / technical (not political) reasons.
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles. What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles. What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
„Go and see“: Have adequate balance of documentation and in-person communication.
„Go and see“: Have adequate balance of documentation and in-person communication.
Establish an open atmosphere, where people trust each other.
Establish an open atmosphere, where people trust each other.
Foster that it is OK to say “no” if it is really well-founded.
Foster that it is OK to say “no” if it is really well-founded.
Establish metrics and try to use the metrics from past projects.
Establish metrics and try to use the metrics from past projects.
Plan based on “reality” and past similar experience rather than “wishful thinking”.
Plan based on “reality” and past similar experience rather than “wishful thinking”.
Use stand-up meetings, lean visualization and retrospectives for asking questions and providing feedback.
Use stand-up meetings, lean visualization and retrospectives for asking questions and providing feedback.
Accept the thinking software is very easy and cheap to change.
Accept the thinking software is very easy and cheap to change.
Support the thinking that political issues as more important than technical or business aspects.
Support the thinking that political issues as more important than technical or business aspects.

The product (lifecycle) manager and the project manager must act as the owner of the main requirements and quality characteristics. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Now you can rank these measures. Start with the most important do to be implemented in your project.

The product (lifecycle) manager and the project manager must act as the owner of the main requirements and quality characteristics. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Now you can rank these measures. Start with the most important do to be implemented in your project.
Make PM / PLM responsible (empowerment, backing, PMP).
Make PM / PLM responsible (empowerment, backing, PMP).
Prioritize and know the top 10 requirements at any time.
Prioritize and know the top 10 requirements at any time.
Enhance domain knowledge of customer domain.
Enhance domain knowledge of customer domain.
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, and allocate requirements. Plan for it!
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, and allocate requirements. Plan for it!
Educate project managers and product managers in requirements engineering techniques.
Educate project managers and product managers in requirements engineering techniques.
Establish a requirements engineering process and assign responsibilities to empowered people.
Establish a requirements engineering process and assign responsibilities to empowered people.
Set up an infrastructure to efficiently develop and manage requirements systematically, available to and used by all on the team.
Set up an infrastructure to efficiently develop and manage requirements systematically, available to and used by all on the team.

The product (lifecycle) manager and the project manager must act as the owner of the main requirements and quality characteristics. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Now you can rank these measures. Start with the most important don't to be implemented in your project.

The product (lifecycle) manager and the project manager must act as the owner of the main requirements and quality characteristics. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Now you can rank these measures. Start with the most important don't to be implemented in your project.
Attempt to build a system to address all stakeholders' inputs.
Attempt to build a system to address all stakeholders' inputs.
Throw the requirements over the fence and expect a finished product as result.
Throw the requirements over the fence and expect a finished product as result.
Delegate the requirements engineering to anyone available in your team.
Delegate the requirements engineering to anyone available in your team.

Work iteratively and test-driven, foster defect prevention and early feedback from the beginning, and strive to identify and resolve risks early. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Please rank these measures. Start with the most important do to be implemented in your project.

Work iteratively and test-driven, foster defect prevention and early feedback from the beginning, and strive to identify and resolve risks early. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Please rank these measures. Start with the most important do to be implemented in your project.
Use lean and agile development methods.
Use lean and agile development methods.
Plan explicitly which increments are done first. This should be based on customer value but also technical risks and topics that have strong effect on architecture.
Plan explicitly which increments are done first. This should be based on customer value but also technical risks and topics that have strong effect on architecture.
Foster continuous testing and defect prevention from the beginning.
Foster continuous testing and defect prevention from the beginning.
Plan fixed length iterations (as short as your organization‘s culture can handle, initially might be one year, later might be 1 month or even 2 weeks).
Plan fixed length iterations (as short as your organization‘s culture can handle, initially might be one year, later might be 1 month or even 2 weeks).
Make detailed plans only of the upcoming increment. For other increments only plan coarse-grained or at high-level information.
Make detailed plans only of the upcoming increment. For other increments only plan coarse-grained or at high-level information.

Work iteratively and test-driven, foster defect prevention and early feedback from the beginning, and strive to identify and resolve risks early. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Please rank these measures. Start with the most important don't to be implemented in your project.

Work iteratively and test-driven, foster defect prevention and early feedback from the beginning, and strive to identify and resolve risks early. Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Please rank these measures. Start with the most important don't to be implemented in your project.
Don’t underestimate that this can be a significant change in organizational cuture.
Don’t underestimate that this can be a significant change in organizational cuture.
Don’t underestimate the challenges if you deal with systems.
Don’t underestimate the challenges if you deal with systems.

children.text: Structure the system to avoid unnecessary complexity, and to actively enable and support multi-site development.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?
Pay particular attention to specifying, testing, and realizing non-functional requirements (NFRs), often overlooked but extremely important.
Which dos and don’ts would you like to implement in your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, allocate, and verify NFRs.
Test the feasibility of the NFRs
Identify conflicts in NFRs and identify overly ambitious NFRs.
Convey the implementation difficulty to the stakeholders instead of just enjoying the technical challenges.
Don’t insist on perfecting NFRs before starting the architectural design or measuring the NFRs of the platform.
Don’t attempt to build a system to address all stakeholders' inputs.
Don’t decide on an NFR’s value without checking the prototype measurements.
Don’t think and design for one NFR without thinking about others.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
Work together truly as a team, avoid “silo” thinking, be willing and able to speak and understand the other roles and disciplines.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?
Work iteratively and test-driven, foster defect prevention and early feedback from the beginning, and strive to identify and resolve risks early.
Here again you see the dos and don‘ts. Now you can rank these measures. Start with the most important do or don’t to be implemented in your project.
Please drag and drop the dos and don’ts into the empty fields.
Use lean and agile development methods.
Plan explicitly which increments are done first. This should be based on customer value but also technical risks and topics that have strong effect on architecture.
Foster continuous testing and defect prevention from the beginning.
Plan fixed length iterations (as short as your organization‘s culture can handle, initially might be one year, later might be 1 month or even 2 weeks).
Make detailed plans only of the upcoming increment. For other increments only plan coarse-grained or at high-level information.
Don’t underestimate that this can be a significant change in organizational cuture.
Don’t underestimate the challenges if you deal with systems.
Build on existing basis where feasible (technical and business) and recognize when reuse is not suitable.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?

children.value: fully realized We have a conscious decision together with Product management what to reuse and what not. Using C/V Analysis.
must be realized We collect what we implemented in other projects and do copy and change

children.text: Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project.
Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?
Here you see a summary of your ratings.
Next you will get a closer look at four aspects of software projects similar to Pandora’s box.
Structure the system to avoid unnecessary complexity, and to actively enable and support multi-site development.
Which dos and don’ts would you like to implement in your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
Enforce a clean top-down structuring of the system by your development team but keep bottom-up constraints in mind.
Support a clean mapping of requirements to architecture decisions (tracing).
Structure your products / solutions according to component-based and service-oriented principles.
Be actively involved and keep yourself informed about the system development.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
“The requirements were written down in the right template and quality management approved them. What more would you want?” says the project manager.
What do you think: In general, how did the team handle the requirements?
Do not underestimate the importance of soft skills, these can be particularly important for convincing and motivating.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?

Nutzerauswahl: gp1:<var>gp_01_010101en</var> gp2:<var>gp_02_010101en</var> gp3:<var>gp_03_010101en</var> gp4:<var>gp_04_010101en</var> gp5:<var>gp_05_010101en</var> gp6:<var>gp_06_010101en</var> gp7:<var>gp_07_010101en</var> gp8:<var>gp_08_010101en</var> gp9:<var>gp_09_010101en</var> gp10:<var>gp_10_010101en</var> gp11:<var>gp_11_010101en</var> gp12:<var>gp_12_010101en</var>mc_11_010101en240:<var>mc_11_010101en240</var>
The importance of architecture activities throughout the whole development process is often underrated.
So it is not a big surprise that the challenges in this discipline are demanding.
They can be divided into three subjects:
What about your own work? Please mark the challenges you want to overcome in your project!
The acceptance of architecture as an important part of software development can be a challenge.
It is a challenge to bring business and architecture together productively.
Some of the challenges in architecture are caused by the approach to architecture itself.

children.value: Throwing over the fence – shifting risks to others.
Extreme distribution of tasks – people have no big picture of the common goal.
Only formal process compliance – people follow the formal process just to avoid being the “guilty” person.
Silo thinking – information is not shared between departments and disciplines work against each other.
Organization shapes architecture – basic architectural decisions are influenced by the organizational structure, while technical arguments are neglected.
First, the project organization chart is built – then the content is discussed.
Responsibilities are unclear or are only formalities – no one feels responsible.
The management overrules the product manager.
The product manager doesn’t prioritize the requirements – everything is the first priority.
The product manager is only the administrator of requirements.
Development drives features – customer needs are neglected.
Always make, never buy – one’s own development is preferred even if it is inefficient.
Platform development aims to build a universal platform.
Platform development is driven only by architecture – customer needs are neglected.
Frustration and demotivation due to organizational problems and cultural misunderstandings
High degree of fluctuation in the global team
We know what our customers want – customers are not (sufficiently) involved in the process.
We do what the customer says – business and system requirements are not (sufficiently) considered.
Architects are not allowed to directly contact the customers.
We jump to solutions without sufficient requirement engineering.
We concentrate only on features and neglect non-functional requirements.
There are thousands of requirements in a single project.
Requirements are frozen – even reasonable changes are almost impossible to realize.
Targets are moving and can’t be fixed.
The specification gets lost in the details, losing the “big picture.”
The specification concentrates on forms and documents, forgetting the goals of the project.
Development starts only if 100% of the requirements are specified.
The complexity of elicitation and specification is underestimated – everybody can do requirement engineering.
Architects are only considered as a service provider or technical expert – they have no responsibilities throughout the entire project.
The architecture quality is not considered as important – when in doubt, feature requests always “win.”
A clean architectural structure is not considered as important.
There is little, if any, time for refactoring.
There are not enough architects on the team.
Always make, never buy – existing standards and technologies are ignored.
Business decisions are political and lack transparency.
The specifications of requirements are poor.
The architecture has to be distributed globally.
The development of platforms is driven by technology, not by product line engineering.
Initial big designs cause unanticipated changes to system and software architectures.
Features are more important than quality.
There is a “wall” between testers and developers – they don’t collaborate and understand each other.
Testers are not involved from the beginning.
The budget and time are too limited for testing.
Tests are not based on business goals and priorities.
Tests start too late – risks are not recognized early enough.
Time and effort for tests are not weighted according to the importance of the risks.
It is unclear who writes the test cases – the product manager, the developer or the tester?
The defect detention rate is not defined – it is not clear how many defects are tolerable.
Non-functional requirements are not tested.Non-functional requirements are not tested.
Testability is not taken into account during requirement engineering and software design.
System is too complex to test.
Software can’t be tested without the hardware.Software can’t be tested without the hardware.#
Testability is not considered a team responsibility.
Code quality and architectural structure is not assessed.
Possible (future) changes or extensions are not considered.

children.text: Nutzerauswahl: gp1:<var>gp_01_010101en</var> gp2:<var>gp_02_010101en</var> gp3:<var>gp_03_010101en</var> gp4:<var>gp_04_010101en</var> gp5:<var>gp_05_010101en</var> gp6:<var>gp_06_010101en</var> gp7:<var>gp_07_010101en</var> gp8:<var>gp_08_010101en</var> gp9:<var>gp_09_010101en</var> gp10:<var>gp_10_010101en</var> gp11:<var>gp_11_010101en</var> gp12:<var>gp_12_010101en</var>
Here you can open a summary of all challenges you identified as relevant for your own project or work.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn ideas and measures to overcome these challenges.
Synchronize and balance (technical and business) well across the disciplines (software, mechanics, electronics, etc.).
Here you see some ideas about how to implement the principle in your day-to-day business.
What do you think of these ideas?
Drive x-functional collaboration and enable frequent interactions across disciplines.
Harmonize technical languages and artifacts of different disciplines.
Use methods and processes as well as best practices for interdisciplinary system modeling.
Use flexible and synergistic engineering methods for partitioning of mechanic, electronic and software engineering to provide new or additional functionality through integration and collaboration.
Use model-based approaches for specification, simulation, implementation, testing.
Identify needed integration levels (data, application, process, service, user interface, device).
Establish common concept for development tool interoperability (ALM and PLM Interoperability).
Avoid unnecessary technological platform development and use available technical standards and products available on the market.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
must be realize: we always build our own platform to be independent from suppliers OR we always trust on of the shelf technologies
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?
As a project manager, you are in charge of the organizational aspects of a development project.
Aligning all disciplines can be a major challenge and it requires a culture of open communication.
In an innovative environment dealing with uncertainty may require an agile process where you replace long planning with iterations of learning and planning.
Iterations, stand-ups, visualization and retrospectives are powerful methods for guiding a development team and getting the instant feedback of progress.
These methods work only when you get contact with your team and discuss current challenges.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn guiding principles to meet this and other challenges.
Think big, act small, fail fast, learn rapidly!

As an architect, you are first of all responsible for the technical solution – over the whole lifetime of the product. That includes setting up an architecture that fulfills the needs of current and future projects and products.
Based on architecture significant requirements like non functional requirements you structure the software product and make important decisions that will be difficult to change later on.
Based on architecture significant requirements like non functional requirements you structure the software product and make important decisions that will be difficult to change later on.
You guide developers and involve them in your decisions and learn together.
In an innovative environment dealing with uncertainty may require an agile process where you replace long specification phases with iterations of learning and strategic design.
Your work is closely connected to all other aspects of the project: business, requirements engineering, testing and quality assurance.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn guiding principles to meet these challenges.
Think big, act small, fail fast, learn rapidly!
Synchronize and balance (technical and business) well across the disciplines (software, mechanics, electronics, etc.).
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?
The product (lifecycle) manager and the project manager must act as the owner of the main requirements and quality characteristics.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
must be realized: We have prioritization. But due to time limits  in the end it is coincidence what ends up in the product.
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.
What other ideas or measures do you have to implement this guiding principle in your work/project?
These are the dos and don’ts you selected as most relevant for your own work or project.
Tip: Review the topics and rank them in order of importance. Then you will have a to-do list which helps you implementing the dos and don’ts in your work.
Pay particular attention to specifying, testing, and realizing non-functional requirements (NFRs), often overlooked but extremely important.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
fully realized: We elicit NFRs even when not given by specs. We question the necessity of aggressive and risky NFRs. We focus on NFRs with the biggest risk and test feasibility.
must be realized: We only implement requirements that are mentioned by the customer / market
Please write down why this principle is relevant to your work/project. Which problems exist because the principle is not (or is inadequately) implemented?
Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.

pages.title: Problem solving {Software architect, Product Manager, Project manager, Software developer, Tester}

children.text: Recognizing the problems in the Pandora’s box project, the R & D manager allows the lead software architect to expand his team.
Think about your own projects: How successful is/was this measure in an advanced stage of a project?

children.value: …a good idea, but difficult to realize in reality.

children.text: The software architect of Pandora’s box claims, “If I would have been involved earlier, the architecture would have been much better.”
How would you rate this statement?

Nutzerauswahl: gp1:<var>gp_01_010101en</var> gp2:<var>gp_02_010101en</var> gp3:<var>gp_03_010101en</var> gp4:<var>gp_04_010101en</var> gp5:<var>gp_05_010101en</var> gp6:<var>gp_06_010101en</var> gp7:<var>gp_07_010101en</var> gp8:<var>gp_08_010101en</var> gp9:<var>gp_09_010101en</var> gp10:<var>gp_10_010101en</var> gp11:<var>gp_11_010101en</var> gp12:<var>gp_12_010101en</var>
Testing is often perceived as a secondary activity, as something “nice to have.” However, testing helps to make quality transparent and visible – and it saves the life-cycle costs of the product.
Testing and quality assurance meet these challenges:
What about your own work? Please mark the challenges you want to overcome in your project!
Testing and quality assurance is sometimes considered an “expensive add-on” that consumes time and budgets.
To test efficiently, tests should follow a risk-based strategy.
One prerequisite for testing is the testability of the system. Sounds self-evident, but an insufficient testability can lead to wasted efforts and high costs.
Internal software (code) quality is a major success factor for maintaining and sustaining a system.
Did you know that the majority of current sales achieved with products, systems, and services are dependent on software?

In this web-based training you will learn some of the typical pitfalls encountered in software projects. You will also learn about practical measures you can use to overcome these weak points in your own project.
Please select the function that best describes your role in a software development project.
As an R & D manager, you lead a project and the whole team behind it.
In addition to the aforementioned challenges, there is one that impacts all the others: the cooperation of your team.
Establish roles and responsibilities and empower your team.
Develop the competencies of your team for the present and future.
Establish a culture of openness, where early (even negative) feedback is welcomed.

Iterations, stand-ups, visualization and retrospectives are powerful methods for guiding a development team and getting the instant feedback of progress. These methods work only when you get contact with your team and discuss current challenges
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn guiding principles to meet these and other challenges.
Think big, act small, fail fast, learn rapidly!
The R & D manager’s approach to this project is “just decide and do it.” That’s why he decided to use the waterfall model, since it was a plain and simple project.
What do you think of his approach?
The R & D Manager’s approach is…
Be prepared and able to handle changing requirements, but be aware about the risk of late changes.
Here’s a list of dos and don’ts we found to be good ideas.
Which of them are interesting for your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
Consider change as the rule but not the exception.
Leverage a lean and agile development paradigm that helps to cope with changing requirements.
Make sure that important, architecturally significant requirements are clarified before design starts.
Apply a commonality/variability analysis to anticipate a potential change and prepare for it.
Keep change in mind when conducting project planning, e.g. plan time for regular architecture assessment and refactoring activities.
Establish a cost/benefit analysis for all changes and decide which changes are really necessary.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
Avoid unnecessary technological platform development and use available technical standards and products available on the market.
Here you see some ideas about how to implement the principle in your day-to-day business.
What do you think of these ideas?
Conduct a thorough market analysis of existing standards and technologies.
Assign high priorities to mandatory standards and common off-the-shelf technologies required to vary across projects.
Check all costs and impacts of adapting the technologies and standards. Compare these costs with providing proprietary solutions.
Collect experience reports from similar project backgrounds.
Reward developers for re-using existing platforms & standards.
Ask customers about technology platforms and standards they take for granted.
Do not underestimate the importance of soft skills, these can be particularly important for convincing and motivating.
What could be done and what should be avoided when implementing this guiding principle in a project?
Please write down your dos and don’ts
In the video, the project manager mentions, “It’s a pity that people work so hard but on the wrong tasks.”
Think about your own projects: How often have you had the same impression looking at your team?
We identified four areas in software-intensive development projects that are essential to running a project efficiently.
The influence of business aspects on software projects
The impact of communication on architecture
Can testing improve a development process?

children.value: Establish a clear scope of products and solutions in the business domain.
Derive a commonality/variability analysis determining all parts that can be re-used or are required to vary across projects.
Prefer reuse over re-implementation by providing a platform that can be shared across multiple products/solutions.
Adapt a test strategy to cope with variability and commonality.
For reuse decisions, balance organizational/business goals and technical merit.
Give rewards for adopting a re-use strategy.
Don’t reuse parts where re-use is not beneficial.

children.text: Build on existing basis where feasible (technical and business) and recognize when reuse is not suitable.
Here’s a list of dos and don’ts we found to be good ideas.
Which of them are relevant to your own work or project?
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your personal to-do list.*

pages.title: How do you rate the project?

children.text: Obviously, the Pandora’s box demonstration was not convincing.
How would you currently rate the project status?
Einen Moment Geduld. Gleich geht es weiter.

pages.title: Does it get any better or just different?

children.value: …is useful up to a certain degree

children.text: The software developer of Pandora’s box challenges testing, asking “Does it get any better or just different?” The project manager seems to be skeptical as well.
What do you think about testing?
Thank you. Actually we don’t share your opinion. Testing is essential and has to be in mind from the very first beginning of a new project.
Thank you. Actually we share the opinion, that testing is essential and has to be in mind from the very first beginning of a new project.
Do not underestimate the importance of soft skills, these can be particularly important for convincing and motivating.
Here’s a list of dos and don’ts we found to be good ideas.
Which of them are interesting for your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
Be aware that „software business is people business“.
Keep in mind, that a systematic and continuous competence development is a key task of each manager.
“Go and See”: Consider system development as collaborative game.
“Go and See”: Establish an open and constructive working environment where different roles can speak up freely.
Try to identify and solve tensions early.
Keep track of effective communication among different stakeholders.
Make sure to educate team members in terms of social skills.
Find out what motivate the individual person.
Establish a “learning from failure and problems” culture and don‘t shoot the messenger. Ask for current challenges, don’t insist on “green” status reports.
Give responsibility and space for own decisions to your team. Let the expert do what he/she can do best (e.g. coding, UI Design, …).
Give honest and constructive feedback to help personal development of team members.
Be aware of  your own personality type and your favorite leadership style and consider that other styles might be adequate for specific situations.
Don’t demotivate people by giving too detailed instructions of what is their area of expertise.
Don’t demotivate people by always giving superfiscally positive or only negative feedback.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
The product (lifecycle) manager (PLM) and the project manager (PM) must act as the owner of the main requirements and quality characteristics.
Here you see some dos and don’ts which can help improve a project according to this guiding principle.
What’s your opinion? Which ideas are useful for your work or project?
Please mark the ideas you would rate as „useful“.
Make product manager and / or project manager responsible (empowerment, backing).
Prioritize and know the top 10 requirements at any time.
Enhance domain knowledge of customer domain.
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, and allocate requirements. Plan for it!
Educate project managers and product managers in requirements engineering techniques and the importance of so called nonfunctional requirements / expected qualities.
Establish a requirements engineering activities and assign responsibilities to empowered people.
Product manager should push through as many requirements as possible.
Product manager should leave out as many features as possible.
Set up an infrastructure to efficiently develop and manage requirements systematically, available to and used by all on the team.
Throw the requirements over the fence to get a finished product as result.
Concentrate on easy requirements and the biggest risks first to ensure feasibility.
Concentrate on the biggest customer benefit first to get a viable product as fast as possible.
Delegate the requirements engineering to anyone available in your team.

As a product manager you are the entrepreneur of your product – over the whole product lifecycle. You are the link between market, business,  development, logistics, procurement and manufacturing. And it is your job to get all parties to a smooth collaboration.
As time and budget is limited prioritization is most important: what NOT to do. Therefore understanding market, customer, users and domain is of the essence.
Getting early feedback from market as well as from your development team (feasibility) is your survival kit.
Dealing with uncertainty may require an agile process where you replace long planning with iterations of learning and planning.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn guiding principles to meet this and other challenges.
Work iteratively and test-driven, foster defect prevention and early feedback from the beginning, and strive to identify and resolve risks early.
Here you see some dos and don’ts which can help improve a project according to this guiding principle.
What’s your opinion? Which ideas are useful for your work or project?
Please mark the ideas you would rate as „useful“.
Use lean and agile development methods.
Plan explicitly which increments are done first. This should be based on customer value but also technical risks and topics that have strong effect on architecture.
Foster continuous testing and defect prevention from the beginning.
Plan fixed length iterations (as short as your organization‘s culture can handle, initially might be one year, later might be 1 month or even 2 weeks).
Make detailed plans only of the upcoming increment. For other increments only plan coarse-grained or at high-level information.
Don’t underestimate that this can be a significant change in organizational culture.
Don’t underestimate the challenges if you deal with systems.
Be prepared and able to handle changing requirements, but be aware about the risk of late changes.
How do you rate the realization of this guiding principle in your work/project?
must be realized: There is no Requirements Freeze.  OR  Requirements are frozen and can not be changed after Milestone X.

Here you see the dos and don’ts, which you previously marked.

children.value: Build a pool of educated, i.e. certified architects and developers.
Consider architecture to be important throughout the entire lifecycle.
Empower architects to fulfill their roles and responsibilities successfully.
Enforce effective and efficient communication between architects and other stakeholders.
Focus on strategic design before turning to tactical design.
Use product-line engineering and platform approaches whenever appropriate.
Don’t emphasize technologies instead of requirements.
Don’t leave out reviews during time-sensitive situations.

Nutzerauswahl: gp1:<var>gp_01_010101en</var> gp2:<var>gp_02_010101en</var> gp3:<var>gp_03_010101en</var> gp4:<var>gp_04_010101en</var> gp5:<var>gp_05_010101en</var> gp6:<var>gp_06_010101en</var> gp7:<var>gp_07_010101en</var> gp8:<var>gp_08_010101en</var> gp9:<var>gp_09_010101en</var> gp10:<var>gp_10_010101en</var> gp11:<var>gp_11_010101en</var> gp12:<var>gp_12_010101en</var>mc_11_010101en190:<var>mc_11_010101en190</var>
Defining requirements that reflect the customer’s needs as well as the development process framework is often an underestimated challenge.
Three groups of requirement engineering challenges can be identified in most projects:
What about your own work? Please mark the challenges you want to overcome in your project!
* Your marks will be used to individualize recommendations in the “Guiding principles” chapter
The elicitation and assessment of requirements is crucial when setting goals for developers.
Changing requirements can cause delays and unforeseen costs. On the other hand there should always be some flexibility to optimize the product during the development process.
Afterwards the elicitation requirements have to be specified.
Strive for transparency and base decisions on clear business / technical (not political) reasons.
Which dos and don’ts would you like to implement in your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
„Go and see“: Have adequate balance of documentation and in-person communication.
„Go and see“: Establish an open atmosphere, where people trust each other.
„Go and see“: Foster that it is OK to say “no” if really it is well-founded.
„Go and see“: Ask your team about their biggest challenges, don’t insist on “green light” status reports.
“Visualization: Establish metrics and try to use the metrics from past projects.
Use stand-up meetings, lean visualization and retrospectives for asking questions and providing feedback.
Plan based on “reality” and past similar experience rather than “wishful thinking”.
Don’t accept the thinking that software is very easy and cheap to change.
Don’t support the thinking that political issues as more important than technical or business aspects.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
We hope these guiding principles gave you some inspiration for your own work and projects.
You can find much more detailed information and how-to recommendations on the Siemens Software Initiative’s (SWI) guiding principles site.
Now you can review the summary of your challenges, your favorite dos and don’ts and your checklists.
As a tester, you are not only showing the current quality of the system under development. You are early involved in planning the quality and testability.
This often challenges your technical expertise alongside your communication and collaboration skills.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn guiding principles to meet this challenge.
Think big, act small, fail fast, learn rapidly.
Structure the system to avoid unnecessary complexity, and to actively enable and support multi-site development.
Here you see some ideas about how to implement the principle in your day-to-day business.
What do you think of these ideas?
Enforce a clean top-down structuring of the system by your development team but keep bottom-up constraints in mind.
Support a clean mapping of requirements to architecture decisions (tracing).
Structure your products / solutions according to component-based and service-oriented principles.
Be actively involved and keep yourself informed about the system development.
Avoid unnecessary technological platform development and use available technical standards and products available on the market.
Which dos and don’ts would you like to implement in your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your personal to-do list.*
Conduct a thorough market analysis of existing standards and technologies.
Assign high priorities to mandatory standards and common off-the-shelf technologies required to vary across projects.
Check all costs and impacts of adapting the technologies and standards. Compare these costs with providing proprietary solutions.
Collect experience reports from similar project backgrounds.
Reward developers for re-using existing platforms & standards.
Ask customers about technology platforms and standards they take for granted.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
“Who takes care of the usability?” is another question asked in the video.
What’s your opinion? Who is in charge of securing a user-friendly design?
Work together truly as a team, avoid “silo” thinking, be willing and able to speak and understand the other roles and disciplines.
Here’s a list of dos and don’ts we found to be good ideas.
Which of them are interesting for your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
Speak common language, use common repository so that all are “on the same page”.
Especially watch for good communication/collaboration between product management and development and between development and testing.
Clearly define processes for the interfaces between roles.
Make sure that everyone has a basic understanding (e.g. through training) of the other important roles.
Offer incentives to individuals but the entire team.
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.

children.value: As soon as the architecture is fixed

children.text: The tester in the video demands to be involved from the beginning to check the testability of the requirements, among other things.
Think about your own projects: At which point are the testers involved in a typical project?
Here you see a summary of all challenges you identified as relevant for your own project or work.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn ideas and measures to overcome these challenges.
Decision-making and inefficient workflows are only two examples of challenges that concern the business side of a software development project.
The challenges can actually be divided into five subjects:
What about your own work? Please mark the challenges you want to overcome in your project!
One of the major challenges in software projects is to establish a process in which all parties work together efficiently.
The organizational structure often has an important influence on the development of software and the software itself.
The product manager should be the central link between customers and developers.
Choosing the right business model for software development is complex because many parameters have to be considered.
Software development done in global teams implies collaboration between teams in distant locations and with different cultural identities.

As a software developer, you are primarily responsible for writing code that fulfills not only the functional and operational requirements given by the customer/market but as well developmental requirements like maintainability.
But your work is closely connected to the other disciplines in a project, particularly requirements engineering, software architecture, testing and quality assurance.
In the next part of this web-based training you will learn guiding principles to meet these and other challenges.
Dealing with uncertainty may require an agile process where you replace long planning with iterations of learning and planning.
Think big, act small, fail fast, learn rapidly.
Work together truly as a team, avoid “silo” thinking, be willing and able to speak and understand the other roles and disciplines.
What could be done and what should be avoided when implementing this guiding principle in a project?
Please write down your dos and don’ts
Synchronize and balance (technical and business) well across the disciplines (software, mechanics, electronics, etc.).
Which dos and don’ts would you like to implement in your own work or project?
Please bookmark the top three dos and don’ts for your to-do-list.*
Drive x-organizational collaboration and enable frequent interactions across disciplines.
Harmonize technical languages and artifacts of different disciplines.
Use methods and processes as well as best practices for interdisciplinary system modeling.
Use flexible and synergistic engineering methods for partitioning of mechanic, electronic and software engineering to provide new or additional functionality through integration and collaboration.
Use model-based approaches for specification, simulation, implementation, testing.
Identify needed integration levels (data, application, process, service, user interface, device).
Establish common concept for development tool interoperability (ALM and PLM Interoperability).
* You can save or print the collected dos and don’ts later.
Strive for transparency and base decisions on clear business / technical (not political) reasons.
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles.
What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Please drag-and-drop the measure to its respective field
„Go and see“: Have adequate balance of documentation and in-person communication.
Accept the thinking software is very easy and cheap to change.
Establish an open atmosphere, where people trust each other.
Support the thinking that political issues as more important than technical or business aspects.
Foster that it is OK to say “no” if it is really well-founded.
Establish metrics and try to use the metrics from past projects.
Plan based on “reality” and past similar experience rather than “wishful thinking”.
Use stand-up meetings, lean visualization and retrospectives for asking questions and providing feedback.
Thanks. Actually we would rate the measures differently.
Pay particular attention to specifying, testing, and realizing non-functional requirements (NFRs), often overlooked but extremely important.
Here you see some measures for implementing the principles.
What do you think: Which measures are Dos and which are Don’ts?
Please drag-and-drop the measure to its respective field
Start early to elicit, consolidate, analyze, validate, allocate, and verify NFRs.
Insist on perfecting NFRs before starting the architectural design or measuring the NFRs of the platform.
Attempt to build a system to address all stakeholders' inputs (only).
Identify conflicts in NFRs and identify overly ambitious NFRs.
Decide on an NFR’s value without checking the prototype measurements.
Convey the implementation difficulty(including time and budget) to the stakeholders instead of just enjoying the technical challenges.
Think and design for the most important NFR without considering others.
Thanks. Actually, we would rate the measures differently.
